txt.en: The Ent rumbles softly as he searches for a voice that has not oft been used for many years.\n\n'Hrum. Where is my little friend? Please bring him to me.'

'They are coming. There will be revenge. There will be justice. Orcs will pollute the Eaves of Fangorn no more.'\n\nThe Ent's eyes now burn with a fire that fills you with fear...fear, admiration, and awe. It is good to be a friend of the Ents, and not an enemy.
Instance: Awake at Long Last
'You have done enough, little [placeholder]. The Ents will take over from here. We cannot slumber while our forest is corrupted by the filth of Saruman....'
The Ent stares down at the bird's lifeless body. A strange expression plays across his eyes.\n\n'I see....'
Defeated an enemy ([placeholder]/[placeholder])
Oldheart stops at the edge of the polluted pond
Oldheart speaks, his voice slow from disuse, but the tone of sadness is unmistakeable
Oldheart stands at the edge of his meadow in Fangorn.\n\nYou should speak with Oldheart.
You have picked up Oldheart's fallen friend
You should follow Oldheart.
Oldheart stops at the edge of the pond and turns around expectantly
You should follow Oldheart.
You awakened the Ents of Fangorn's eaves
You should talk to Oldheart.
The dead bird can be found in the middle of the murky, foul pond.
Oldheart is at the pond's edge in Fangorn.
Oldheart is in Fangorn.
The Ents are awake....
Tell Oldheart of the little bird's fate
Follow Oldheart and defend yourself from enemies ([placeholder]/[placeholder])
Follow Oldheart
Talk to Oldheart
Pick up the little bird
Bring the bird to Oldheart
Follow Oldheart
Speak with Oldheart, for the other Ents approach
You have found Oldheart's little bird-friend...dead, suffocated by the pollutants of the Orcs and Uruks crossing Fangorn from Isengard to Rohan.

You are tempted to lie to Oldheart to spare the Ent his feelings, but it will not do. Those keen eyes will see through it at once.\n\nYou gently relay your tale to Oldheart, of the Orcs of Saruman, the sullied water, and the little victim -- a bird that did nothing but pass unwitting through the cloud of death that creeps upon all the lands of Middle-earth.
